newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICAN GREENS ASSURED ON IRON PLANT PROJECT.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICAN GREENS ASSURED ON IRON PLANT PROJECT.

text.p: The Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) had committed itself to a thorough environmental impact assessment study on a planned new iron plant, Trade and Industry Minister Alec Erwin said on Thursday.
The Iron Direct Reduction (IDR) plant would use natural gas from Mozambique's Pande gas field, Erwin said in response to a question tabled in parliament.
It would involve the production of iron from magnetite stockpiled in Phalaborwa, using natural gas from Pande as a fuel and reductant.

The possibility of the magnetite being piped to a site in Mozambique through the Kruger National Park has caused an outcry among conservationists, who fear that this could spark the widespread commercial exploitation of the reserve.

"The IDC has committed itself to a comprehensive Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) conducted by independent professionals in accordance with the most stringent South African, Mozambican and international standards," Erwin said.
Magnetite is a waste product from copper operations at Phalaborwa and has been accumulating in stockpiles for more than 30 years.
"These stockpiles contain more than 200 million tonnes of magnetite and are still growing at a rate of about six million tonnes a year," Erwin said.

The IDR plant would provide an ideal anchor client for the Pande gas field near Inhassorro, about 600 km northeast of Maputo, which the Mozambican government and American energy firm Enron Corp wanted to develop.
"Many options are possible. For example, the plant could be situated in Phalaborwa, Maputo or possibly elsewhere in Mozambique," Erwin said.
Gas could be piped from Pande to Maputo, Phalaborwa or another site in Mozambique. The magnetite could be railed to Maputo or pumped there in the form of slurry.
"Competent local and international consultants have been appointed to assist the IDC in conducting a feasibility study and all sensible options will be evaluated," he said.
Initial estimates were that a pipeline between Phalaborwa and Maputo would cost about 900 million rand ($201 million) while the entire IDR project would cost about 5.2 billion rand.

Erwin said the project could earn both countries about 2.05 billion rand combined and create about 500 direct permanent jobs and another 1,600 indirect jobs. The life expectancy of the project was estimated to be at least 30 years.
